channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.

item.title: Superconductivity in Sr-doped La<sub>3</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> thin films
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 18 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02327-2

The authors study the effects of heterovalent doping on superconducting bilayer nickelate thin films.
item.dc:title: Superconductivity in Sr-doped La<sub>3</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> thin films
item.dc:creator: Bo Hao

item.title: A solid electrolyte with active stability
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 15 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02323-6

Halide solid electrolytes are shown to be dynamically stable beyond their thermodynamic reduction potential via reversible lithiation–delithiation, reaching 0.2 V versus Li+/Li and enabling high-capacity phosphorus-based anodes.
item.dc:title: A solid electrolyte with active stability
item.dc:creator: Matteo Bianchini

item.title: Unconventional scaling of the orbital Hall effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 15 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02326-3

Scattering in the archetypal oxide SrRuO3 is shown to enhance orbital currents. This counter-intuitive effect establishes a transformative paradigm for energy-efficient spintronic devices.
item.dc:title: Unconventional scaling of the orbital Hall effect
item.dc:creator: Siyang Peng

item.title: Scalable photonic quantum technologies
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 14 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02306-7

Photonic platforms are a prominent host on which practical quantum information technology applications can be leveraged and scaled. The authors discuss the state-of-the-art capabilities and give an outlook on optical technologies towards the realization of quantum computation, communications and metrology.
item.dc:title: Scalable photonic quantum technologies
item.dc:creator: Hui Wang
Timothy C. Ralph
Jelmer J. Renema
Chao-Yang Lu
Jian-Wei Pan
